questions.question_text: Multiple business accounts were compromised a few days after a public website had its credentials database leaked on the Internet. No business emails were identified in the breach, but the security team thinks that the list of passwords exposed was later used to compromise business accounts. Which of the following would mitigate the issue?

discussion.content: Don't really feel like any of the answers are sufficient. Would be looking for something like MFA for this.

comments.content:
Yeah. A few days after the breach, the passwords were a vulnerability? Password history would not be realistic for this scenario. If it said 7 months later, that would make more sense. 

Imagine having a 24-hour password policy :cry:
I concur

It doesn't make sense. It's known fact, that users use the same password changing the last one-two digits to comply with "pasword history" requirement. Password complexity helps to preserve policies, at least. I believe, here no good option. Idk why they ask to choose better from worst.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Password reuse is an important concern in any organization. Many users want to reuse the same password for their account over a long period of time.

Selected Answer: B
B. Password history

First, antster1000 is right, but my take is this: when the questions asks "Which of the following would mitigate the issue?", isn't it suggested that means how do we prevent this from happening in the first place? In which case I would lean towards C. So... A - definitely important, but the questions suggests that passwords were compromised anyway. Same for B.
B. Password history This would keep accounts secure as past passwords, which are now public, would be useless.

Selected Answer: B
Password History is the best answer. The password history policy prevents users from reusing their old passwords (because their old passwords are found in the leaked password list.)

Selected Answer: B
B. Password history

comments.content: Isn't the issue that a password used at the company by staff was also being used on personal accounts? Therefore password history would force them to change the password at the company, which would then be different to any leaked passwords?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct Answer: 
A. Complexity requirements, Because having stronger and more complex passwords makes it harder for attackers to use leaked passwords from other breaches to compromise accounts. If users have complex passwords that are unique to each service they use, the likelihood of a password from one service being valid on another is reduced.

Other Answer: 
B. Password history, This ensures users don't reuse recent passwords, but it wouldn't necessarily prevent the use of passwords from an external leak if a user used the same password on multiple platforms.

C. Acceptable use policy, While this sets guidelines for how IT resources can be used, it doesn't directly address the password reuse issue.

D. Shared accounts, Shared accounts typically present more of a security risk rather than mitigating issues, as multiple individuals have access to the same account and it's harder to track individual actions.

comments.content: Yeah, it's disheartening with how much effort we put into studying and then there are so many of these poorly worded questions. Even cybersecurity professionals struggle with these questions.

discussion.content: Answers for the exam and answers that make since in the real world aren't always the same. Once I pass I'm memory dumping all this BS.

comments.content: Dude, I was telling my friend the exact same thing today. Every question is worded in a way that more than one answer is correct and depending on who wrote the question the answer changes. Everything is a trick question instead of testing for basic knowledge
The receptionist
They must have one funny looking receptionist.

discussion.content: All of the choices are crap...not sure if this question is reflective of the real world, or has any value. They are more concerned with tricking with words rather than validating you knowledge. What clown is authoring these questions?

I don't understand these questions, i starting to understand the comments about these questions. Should mitigate the problem right now be have them all change their passwords.... history doesn't matter if there is no age? If they have the database of passwords then they are running a rainbow attack on it somewhere and going to just get more passwords if no one changes it? force a password change, add age and history...

comments.content: These answers are in fact bad but password history would be ideal out of all of them. A better choice would be password age.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Password history is the least bad of these bad answers.
"... was later used" is a our key statement here.

Selected Answer: C
The scenario indicates business accounts have been compromised in an aftermath of a non-related security incident. Meaning the malicious actors got information from the leaked information and used the same on corporate accounts which evidently also got compromised because the end-users must have reused passwords. Hence an acceptable policy against password reuse would have mitigated the secondary incident. (logic appears sound but open to debate)

Selected Answer: B
Implementing password history would be an effective measure to mitigate the issue of compromised business accounts in this scenario. Password history keeps track of previously used passwords, and users are not allowed to reuse old passwords when creating a new one. This prevents attackers from reusing leaked passwords to gain unauthorized access to business accounts, even if the leaked credentials are known to them.

By enforcing password history, organizations can improve their security posture and protect against credential reuse attacks.

Selected Answer: B
I think given the information we have it would be password history.

Selected Answer: B
Password history: Implementing a password history policy ensures that users cannot reuse their previously used passwords. This prevents attackers from reusing compromised passwords to gain unauthorized access to business accounts. By maintaining a password history, users are forced to choose unique passwords each time they update their credentials.
I would say B password history, keyword "exposed was later used"

Selected Answer: A
None of the options are correct. This is another question that sucks. Comptia charges almost 400 dollars for the exam and gives us this nonsense in return. kudos to them.

comments.content: It doesn't say that the leaked credentials were hashes, it says "list of passwords". So, the complexity would mean nothing when you have a password in a clear text.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Complexity requirements is the only solution that makes sense.

An AUP dictates what a user may do with corporate systems, it does not address how the
 user should manage their passwords, that would be Code of Conduct or some other policy.

Password history only serves to prevent password reuse on the corporate network; it will do nothing to prevent the user from using the same passwords on a public site. MAYBE, had the question stated that the password database was old, then password history may make sense, but even then complexity is the better answer.

A shared account would absolutely do nothing to help with this.

So by elimination we can say it's complexity. However, it intuitively makes sense. A leaked password database would contain password hashes that need to be cracked, weak passwords are trivial to extract using rainbow table or dictionary attacks while complex passwords may never be recovered from a leaked password database. Thus the hacker will have a list of weak passwords they will use in their attack. Enforcing complex passwords nullifies that list.
Password history > enforces new passwords > makes the leaked passwords irrelevant

Selected Answer: C
Password History only means that once the password leaked, all compromised password should be changed or reset differently

Isn't password history about how long a password can be used before it can be changed? 
I don't see how it applies here.
The problem here is users using their corporate passwords on other non-corporate sites
I think Acceptable use policy should address this.

Selected Answer: B
A. Complexity requirements and B. Password history are two effective controls to mitigate password-related issues, including the use of weak passwords or the reuse of previously compromised passwords. By enforcing password complexity requirements, organizations can require users to use stronger passwords that are more difficult to guess or crack. By enforcing password history, organizations can prevent users from reusing previously used passwords or the recently compromised ones. This would make it harder for attackers to gain unauthorized access to business accounts using previously leaked passwords.

Selected Answer: B
Another question that the answer really don't address the questions or issue.
this question was not clear tho

Selected Answer: B
FACTS: 
- DB LEAKED ON THE INTERNET
- NO BUSINESS EMAILS WERE IDENTIFIED IN THE BREACH

ASSUMPTIONS
- The security team THINKS that the list of passwords exposed was later used to compromised business accounts, meaning they are guessing on something they are unsure, but their assumption is valid since even thought no business emails were identified in the breach, somehow the attackers were able to access those accounts leading us to believe they were able to do that by trying password that were in this LEAKED DB. SO, my answer is B.
B. Password History. But hopefully the passwords were changed by the time the credentials were leaked. Would be the BEST answer of the choices listed.

Selected Answer: B
Answer: Password History

Password history policies determines the number of unique new passwords that must associated with a user's account before an old password be reused. Essentially forcing users to create new passwords on a regular basis. 

For this situation, forcing users to use new unique passwords would somewhat mitigate the issue.

comments.content: This also would prevent a user from using the same compromised password to quickly. Once the password is compromised hackers can try the old password months later to see if the user was dumb enough to use it again.

password history does not force users to create new passwords. I could set password history to infinity, but if I don't set password expiration the user will only ever have one password (unless they change it on their own). History only prevents reuse.

An AUP addresses acceptable use of the corporate systems. If it was Code of Conduct or Rules of Behaviour I would agree, but user behaviour with regard to passwords would not typically be in the Acceptable Use Policy.

I agree with this because it states in the question that no business emails (accounts) were compromised and that a public facing website (like facebook) was compromised. The question implies that people within the company are reusing company passwords on personal public accounts - against any well thought out AUP. 

Please someone correct me if I'm wrong I want to pass O.o

Here's an example of the wording the AUP might have: "Refrain from using the same password for personal and corporate accounts."
https://resources.infosecinstitute.com/topics/management-compliance-auditing/acceptable-use-policy-template-user-level-passwords/

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It's an acceptable use policy violation. The users are using company passwords on external systems.

Selected Answer: B
It's not the other three.

comments.content: I was thinking same, but if the passwords were leaked, the passwords would be able to be seen, the complexity would not matter. I think B is the better choice, with the reasoning that hopefully passwords were changed by the time they were leaked.

discussion.content: Limited password lifetime or MFA would be the best answers here. Nevertheless I vote for A. My reasoning: The website pwd list was used for a dictionary attack on the company. Complexitiy requirements would reduce the risk, that the password list produced "hits" on the companies' accounts, which were not used on the hacked website.

comments.content: You're thinking of a group policy. AUPs are only for prohibited websites and apps for personal use.

an AUP does not address how the users set passwords. It is limited to what the user does with corporate systems and data. Code of Conduct or Rules of Behaviour might address the need for the user to use unique passwords for their corporate accounts.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
To me the Answer is C. Enforcing password history would not prevent the users from using the same password on multiple sites, which is what is being implied here. An AUP (Acceptable Use Policy) Could at least hold users responsible for using the same password on multiple sites, although would also not prevent them.

comments.content: Password history relies on password expiration policy but we don't know if such policy exists! But the fact that they used company account password in public sites, means current AUP policy (password section) needs to be added or updated.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I agree with password history but I am not convinced the public website and the buisness accounts are linked to the same company or entity. That said Password history controls would not come into play as neither entities would know of the others user password history. That said the AUP would be able to address password reuse across unaffiliated accounts. That said the question is poorly worded and needs revision.
I agree with Password History here. I was looking for MFA among the list of answers!

Selected Answer: B
MFA would be the optimal answer here, password reuse would be secondary - but since neither are available as answers, it has to be password history.

Selected Answer: B
Looks like they're reusing the passwords

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the final step of the incident response process?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
this answer is true

Choose A
this came on my exam 4-12-2026

comments.content: 2026? lmao
John Connor sent him

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Lessons learned

The final step in the incident response process is typically "Lessons learned." This phase involves a comprehensive review and analysis of the incident to identify what went well, what could be improved, and what lessons can be drawn to enhance the organization's overall security posture. The objective is to learn from the incident and use that knowledge to strengthen preventive and responsive measures for the future.

Selected Answer: A
A. Lessons learned

Selected Answer: A
lessons learned is the last step

questions.question_text:
A systems administrator is redesigning how devices will perform network authentication. The following requirements need to be met:

• An existing internal certificate must be used.
• Wired and wireless networks must be supported.
• Any unapproved device should be isolated in a quarantine subnet.
• Approved devices should be updated before accessing resources.

Which of the following would best meet the requirements?

comments.content: 802* score

discussion.content:
choose A
2024-20-2 On Test and passed with 80

Selected Answer: A
A. 802.1X

802.1X can provide the foundation for network authentication, allowing devices to authenticate themselves before gaining access to the network. When used in conjunction with a robust NAC solution, it can also facilitate device isolation and update mechanisms to meet the specified requirements.

Selected Answer: A
A. 802.1X

All answers provide some authentication but the best answer would be 802.1x
802.1x meets all the requirements of the question.
The other three: EAP, RADIUS and WP2 do not satisfy all question requirements.

Selected Answer: A
A. 802.1X meets all the coditions

Selected Answer: A
802.1X

questions.question_text: An IT security team is concerned about the confidentiality of documents left unattended in MFPs. Which of the following should the security team do to mitigate the situation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
choose B
2024-20-2 On Test and passed with 802

Selected Answer: B
B. Deploy an authentication factor that requires in-person action before printing.

To mitigate the concern about the confidentiality of documents left unattended in Multi-Function Printers (MFPs), deploying an authentication factor that requires in-person action before printing is a recommended security measure. This can be achieved through various means, such as requiring users to physically authenticate themselves at the MFP using a smart card, PIN, or biometric authentication before the documents are printed.

comments.content: The company I work for has this in place. I have to enter my PIN number in order to get the printer to print what I've sent to it.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
They leave papers inside the device after using it.

Selected Answer: A
The answer is A
It mentions for unattended documents, after printing, none of those are the right answer after a document is printed, but A, educate users.

comments.content: "documents are left unattended in MFPs...." How does encryption come in?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
when talking about confidentiality, encryption should just stand out right away. B does not address documents left unattended IN the MFP. Encryption would protect documents in the MFP.

Not sure that right answer is B.
Document left unattended could be also a paper used for a copy and left in it, so.
Multifunction peripheral (Printer, Scanner, Copier) you're welcome.

Selected Answer: B
Answer B is awkwardly phrased, but what I think it's saying is: there needs to be an authentication action done at the printer itself, before the documents are printed. Seems to be the right answer

Selected Answer: B
B. Deploy an authentication factor that requires in-person action before printing.

im going with b
https://www.certblaster.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/CompTIA-Security-SY0-601-Exam-Objectives-1.0.pdf
heres a list of the acronyms and objectives

choices.B: Deploy an authentication factor that requires in-person action before printing.
choices.D: Update the management software to utilize encryption.
choices.A: Educate users about the importance of paper shredder devices.
choices.C: Install a software client in every computer authorized to use the MFPs.

choices.A: A user performed a MAC cloning attack with a personal device.
choices.C: An administrator bypassed the security controls for testing.
choices.B: A DHCP failure caused an incorrect IP address to be distributed
choices.D: DNS hijacking let an attacker intercept the captive portal traffic.
